title: 103_s1208
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government before the National Park Service took over preservation duties. However, financial constraints have hindered the government from meeting the capital needs of these sites. The Congress acknowledges the financial constraints hindering the maintenance of historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall. Minting a commemorative coin is proposed to aid in funding their preservation. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will depict the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, and be legal tender. The silver for the coins will be sourced from stockpiles established under a specific Act. The design for the coins authorized by this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility for a period of up to one year after enactment. SEC. 7. SALE OF THE COINS.

(a) Sale Price.--Coins sold at face value plus surcharge and design costs. Bulk sales at discount, prepaid orders accepted at discount. Surcharge of $7 per coin.

SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to goods/services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment laws required.

SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

50 percent of surcharges from coin sales go to the U.S. Treasury to reduce national debt, while the other 50 percent goes to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for park improvements. 

SEC. 10. AUDITS.

The Comptroller General can audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditures related to the surcharge amounts. SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND. The coins issued under this Act are subject to section 5134 of title 31, United States Code, relating to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for coin issuance and require adequate security or payment guarantees.
